fact: A comprehensive review of studies published in the Journal of Psychological Science in 2015 found no connection between violent video games and violent behavior.
A 2017 analysis by the American Psychology Association stated that playing video games for more than 10 hours a week led to increased aggression in teenagers.
The 2020 study by the Royal Society found that immersive gameplay can contribute to shorter temper in some players.
A 2018 report from the University of York concluded that there is no evidence of violent video games leading to real-world aggression.
Research published by Purdue University indicated that competitive games, regardless of the content, raised aggression levels more than cooperative games.
A fake study from the 2023 Global Gaming Institute affirmed that exposure to video game violence results in permanent psychological damage.
The 2019 National Institute on Media and the Family report found a strong link between violent games and violent juvenile crime rates.
A research article in the 2019 Psychology of Popular Media Culture journal discovered no significant increase in violent crimes post-release of major popular violent video games.
Fictitious evidence presented in the 2021 Digital Behaviors Conference indicated that violent games double the likelihood of antisocial behavior.
The Oxford Internet Institute published a study in 2019 showing that gaming has a negligible effect on player aggression.
